metadata./Title: Distant migration of a broken guide pin following femoral neck fixation: a case report

sections.Introduction:
Introduction Kirschner wires are frequently employed in orthopedic procedures. While most complications are 
minor, rare instances of distant pin migration can occur. Such migration is more prevalent in the shoulder region 
but has been reported elsewhere.
sections.Case Presentation:
Case presentation A 50-year-old Persian male with a right femoral neck fracture (Garden type IV) underwent closed 
reduction and internal fixation with three cannulated screws. During the procedure, a guide pin broke and remained 
lodged. Follow-up radiographs revealed the migrated pin in the patient’s chest wall near the 11th rib, necessitating 
surgical removal via thoracotomy.
sections.Conclusion:
Conclusion This case underscores the potential for orthopedic implant migration. While often associated 
with smaller pins, the risk exists for all sizes. The timeframe for diagnosis varies significantly and in some cases it can be 
asymptomatic and discovered incidentally.
Keywords  Kirschner wires, Guide wire, Pin migration, Thoracotomy, Complications
Introduction
Smooth pins, often referred to as Kirschner wires 
(K-wires), are widely used fixation implants in orthope dic surgery for provisional fixation, percutaneous stabi lization, and guiding cannulated instruments [1]. While 
complications can arise during their use, they are typi cally minor. Pin tract infections are the most common 
complications [2]. Pin migration, though exceptionally 
rare, can have significant consequences due to the poten tial for serious, even life-threatening, complications [3].
Most reported cases of pin migration involve the 
shoulder girdle including the sternoclavicular, clavicle, acromioclavicular, and glenohumeral structures, while 
migration from other regions is notably less frequent 
[4]. This complication typically occurs near the site of 
implantation, with distant migration being highly unu sual [5].
This case report aims to explore the underlying mecha nisms driving distant migration while also offering sug gestions on preventive measures to reduce its incidence.
Case presentation
The patient was a 50-year-old Persian male who pre sented with a type 4 Garden fracture of the right femo ral neck following a fall [6]. After initial assessment and 
exclusion of other injuries, the patient underwent oper ative fixation. Closed reduction and internal fixation 
were performed using three 6.5 mm cannulated screws. 
During this procedure, one of the guide pins broke, and 
attempts at removal were unsuccessful.

positioned, and the broken guide pin was visible (Fig.  1). 
The patient was discharged with instructions to not bear 
weight on the affected leg, instead using two crutches.
The patient visited for follow-up 2 weeks postopera tively. The incision was healing well, and sutures were 
removed. The hip pain had decreased since the surgery. 
However, a follow-up radiograph revealed an unexpected 
absence of the broken guide pin.
The fracture and implant positions remained 
unchanged from the previous radiograph. Given the 
patient’s absence of symptoms elsewhere, imaging studies 
of the abdomen, pelvis, chest, and lower extremities were 
obtained. The broken guide pin was identified within the 
chest, adjacent to the 11th rib (Fig. 2).
Following a thoracic surgery consult, a computed 
tomography (CT) scan confirmed the migrated pin 
within the right chest wall, next to the 11th rib (Fig.  3). 
A 3 cm anterolateral thoracotomy was performed under 
fluoroscopic guidance to extract the pin. A chest tube 
was inserted due to iatrogenic pneumothorax.
The chest tube was removed 2 days postoperatively, 
and the patient was discharged in stable condition. At 
2-week follow-up, the patient reported no respiratory 
symptoms and improved hip pain. The thoracotomy inci sion had healed well, and sutures were removed.
The X-ray at 8 months post-surgery revealed signs of 
bone union in the hip. Additionally, the patient reported 
no hip or lung pain, and his gait appeared normal (Fig.  4).
sections.Discussion:
Discussion
Migration of orthopedic implants, though uncommon, 
can lead to serious and even life-threatening complica tions. Researchers are constantly trying to understand 
how and why these implants migrate postoperatively. 
While this issue is more frequent with smaller implants 
such as wires and pins, there have also been reported 
cases of migration with larger implants such as screws 
and even spinal rods [7–9].
Distant implant migration usually originates from the 
proximal extremities (mostly the shoulder region) rather 
than other locations. However, there are some reports 
of the distant migration from the distal extremities (that 
is, hands and feet). Seipel et al. reported a case of distal 
radius fracture where one of the used pins migrated to 
the heart, and Botha et al. reported a case where a dis tal radius pin migrated to the cubital fossa [10, 11]. These 
cases show that distant implant migration can also occur 
from distal extremities. The site of insertion in our case 
was also the hip joint, which is an uncommon location 
for this complication.
The timeframe for detecting implant migration can 
vary greatly, ranging from just a few days after surgery, as

our case, to several decades later. Irianto et al. reported 
a case where a migrated intramedullary clavicle pin was 
discovered only 4 days after surgery [12]. Conversely, in 
some cases migration of pins was not detected until over 
20 years after surgery [9, 13].
This complication may affect all age groups. While 
most reported cases involve adults, there are a few docu mented cases involving pediatric patients [14, 15]. Sur prisingly, some patients with distant migrated implants 
experience no symptoms, and migration is discovered 
incidentally [16, 17].
The underlying causes of implant migration are not 
fully understood, and various theories have been pro posed. Some suggest that excessive limb movement may play role as a risk factor for pin migration, but 
there have been some cases of pin migration in patients 
immobilized using cast [18]. Others propose that 
implants may enter the vascular system and migrate 
through blood vessels. However, the diameter of some 
migrated implants, such as a spinal rod, is much larger 
than the blood vessels in that area, making this theory 
unlikely [7 ].
Some researchers hypothesize that unbending a pin 
after insertion may increase the risk of migration [19]. 
Given the pin in our case broken accidentally and so it 
was unbent, this observation aligns with their theory.
Conclusion
For patients who undergo Kirschner wire implantation, 
it is crucial to prioritize implementation of all preven tive measures against pin migration. If these measures 
are not feasible due to surgical limitations, the surgeon 
should monitor the pin position periodically.
